column1: TI  - Single-cell RNA-seq supports a developmental hierarchy in human
AB  - Although human tumours are shaped by the genetic evolution of cancer cells
evidence also suggests that they display hierarchies related to developmental
pathways and epigenetic programs in which cancer stem cells (CSCs) can drive
tumour growth and give rise to differentiated progeny. Yet
CSCs in solid human malignancies remains elusive. Here we profile 4
cells from six IDH1 or IDH2 mutant human oligodendrogliomas by RNA sequencing
(RNA-seq) and reconstruct their developmental programs from genome-wide
expression signatures. We infer that most cancer cells are differentiated along

column2: whereas a rare subpopulation of cells is

column1: undifferentiated and associated with a neural stem cell expression program. Cells
with expression signatures for proliferation are highly enriched in this rare

column2: consistent with a model in which CSCs are primarily responsible

column1: for fuelling the growth of oligodendroglioma in humans. Analysis of copy number
variation (CNV) shows that distinct CNV sub-clones within tumours display similar

column2: suggesting that the architecture of oligodendroglioma is

column1: primarily dictated by developmental programs. Subclonal point mutation analysis

column2: although a full phylogenetic tree would be required to

column1: definitively determine the effect of genetic evolution on the inferred
hierarchies. Our single-cell analyses provide insight into the cellular
architecture of oligodendrogliomas at single-cell resolution and support the

column2: with substantial implications for disease management.
